questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a characteristic of growth hormone (GH) deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Hyperglycemia is not a characteristic of GH deficiency. Isolated GH deficiency, especially in 
children, can lead to a higher propensity to develop hypoglycemia. This is attributed to the 
relatively unopposed action of insulin. Isolated GH deficiency in children is associated with the following features: • Short stature • Micropenis • Increased fat • High-pitched voice • High propensity to develop hypoglycemia due to relatively unopposed insulin action. 62 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A 3-year-old girl is referred to your centre for evaluation of short stature. The child's parents 
are found to be first cousins. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of Laron-type dwarfism. 
What causes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-receptor 
anomalies. Laron-type dwarfism is an autosomal recessive disorder. The primary clinical symptom associated 
with this condition is short stature. Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth 
factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone), often called IGF-1.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 9-year-old girl who presented with short stature is diagnosed with Turner’s syndrome. The 
physician decides to initiate treatment with recombinant human growth hormone for short 
stature. Which of the following side effects is she not likely to develop?
questions.explanation:
GH is a potent counter-regulatory hormone to insulin and leads to hyperglycemia, 
thus contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled diabetes. Side effects of GH administration include: • Dose-related fluid retention • Hyperglycemia • Joint pain and carpal tunnel syndrome • Headache, increased intracranial pressure, hypertension • Tinnitus • Pituitary tumor regrowth • Progression of skin lesions • Acromegaly • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis • Gynecomastia The actions of GH are: • Induces protein synthesis and nitrogen retention • Impairs glucose tolerance by antagonizing insulin action • Stimulates lipolysis • Promotes sodium, potassium, and water retention • Elevates serum levels of inorganic phosphate • Linear bone growth occurs • Stimulates epiphyseal prechondrocyte differentiation

questions.question:
Question 4: 57 
Sold by @itachibot Paradoxical response of GH release to thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is seen in all of 
the following conditions except
questions.explanation:
63 
Sold by @itachibot The paradoxical response of GH release to TRH is not seen in malnutrition patients. In normal individuals, GH doesn't respond to TRH stimulation, but paradoxically, the GH levels 
may increase in response to TRH stimulation in the following conditions: • Acromegaly • Prolactinoma • Anorexia nervosa The exact mechanism underlying this paradoxical GH response is poorly understood.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of progressive enlargement of hands and feet 
and was diagnosed with acromegaly. What is the most common cause for this condition?

options.c: GH and PRL secretion from mixed somatotroph-lactotroph adenoma
options.d: GH and PRL secretion from mixed somatotroph-thyrotroph adenoma

questions.explanation: The most common cause of acromegaly is GH secretion from somatotrope adenoma. Causes of acromegaly: • Pituitary - 98% • Somatotrope adenoma - 60% - most common. • Mixed somatotroph-lactotroph adenoma • Other plurihormonal tumors. • Extrapituitary tumor-producing GH: Pancreatic Islet cell tumor • Excess GHRH secretion • Central - hypothalamic hamartoma • Peripheral - bronchial carcinoid

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following features will you expect to see in a patient with acromegaly?
questions.explanation:
Impaired glucose tolerance, galactorrhea, and hypertension can be seen in patients with 
acromegaly. GH secretion is a part of the counter-regulatory defense mechanism against hypoglycemia. 
Physiological GH secretion is inhibited by hyperglycemia. In acromegaly or gigantism, GH 
secretion is autonomous and not suppressed by glucose. Thus, its diagnosis can be confirmed by 
demonstrating the failure of GH suppression with an oral glucose load (impaired oral glucose 
tolerance test). Galactorrhea is due to hyperprolactinemia and hypertension is secondary to increased aldosterone 
levels in acromegaly. GH leads to increased production of vitamin D3 which results in increased 
phosphate absorption from the intestine and decreased renal excretion. Hence there is increased 
serum phosphate level.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged man presented to the OPD with complaints of difficulty in chewing and a 
gradual change in voice over the last year. Examination revealed coarse facial features. The 
image of his hand (right side) compared to the physician's hand is shown below. Which of the 
following long-term complications would you not commonly see in this patient? 58 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
64 
Sold by @itachibot The given scenario and the enlarged hands in the patient, as shown in the image, point towards a 
diagnosis of acromegaly. Diabetes insipidus is not a feature of acromegaly, but diabetes mellitus 
can develop in patients with acromegaly. Clinical features of acromegaly are: Note: Diabetes insipidus can be seen as a complication post Transsphenoidal Surgery for pituitary 
adenomas and other sellar tumours not as complication of Acromegaly per se. System

questions.question:
Question 8: The middle-aged man shown in the image, noticed that his shoes no longer fit him and his 
finger ring is getting tightened. Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels are elevated. Which 
of the following tests will help to confirm the diagnosis?

options.a: Insulin-like Growth Factor -1 Binding Protein - 3 (IGFBP-3) level

questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the presence of coarse facial features and prognathism, as shown in the 
image, points towards a diagnosis of acromegaly. An oral glucose tolerance test with GH levels is 
used to confirm acromegaly.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 44-year-old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. 
During examination, you note that the patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features and 
prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening 
method for this condition?

options.a: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level
options.b: Insulin-like growth factor-1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) level

questions.explanation:
The best screening test for acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 
(IGF-1) level. Other options: Options A and B: Oral glucose challenge test with growth hormone (GH) levels is used for further 
confirmation of the diagnosis. Increased insulin-like growth factor-1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) 
levels can also be seen in patients with acromegaly. But they are not typically used as initial 
screening methods. Option D: IGF-1 levels are more reliable than random GH levels because GH secretion is pulsatile. 
IGF-1 levels reflect long-term exposure to GH and provide a more stable indicator of excessive GH 
production. Acromegaly is characterized by excessive GH secretion, usually caused by a somatotrope adenoma 
in the pituitary gland. It can also be due to ectopic GH secretion or hypothalamic tumors. The clinical presentation of acromegaly includes frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, 
coarse facial features, mandibular prognathism, widened space between lower incisors and other 
manifestations such as soft tissue swelling, deepening voice, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthropathy, 
and acanthosis nigricans. 66 
Sold by @itachibot It can also lead to cardiovascular complications (cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, 
and hypertension), obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, an increased risk of colon polyps, 
and colonic malignancy. The primary treatment for acromegaly is surgical resection of GH-secreting adenomas. 
Somatostatin receptor ligands like octreotide and lanreotide, which suppress GH and IGF-1 levels, 
are used as adjuvant treatment or when surgery is not possible or unsuccessful. Radiation therapy 
may be considered for patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to medical therapy. Other 
treatment options include GH receptor antagonists like pegvisomant and dopamine agonists like 
cabergoline.

questions.question:
Question 10: The medical management of acromegaly includes all the following therapeutic strategies 
except
questions.explanation:
Levodopa is not used in the treatment of acromegaly. Studies have proven that it is not as effective 
as agents like cabergoline. Medical management of acromegaly includes: • Somatostatin analogs: • Octreotide • Lanreotide • Pasireotide • GH-receptor antagonists: • Pegvisomant • Dopamine agonists: • Bromocriptine • Cabergoline

questions.question:
Question 11: A 27-year-old woman presents to the OPD with infertility and amenorrhea. She also 
complains of milky discharge from the nipple. Her urine pregnancy test was negative and her 
prolactin level was 45 ng/ml. Which of the following drugs cannot lead to this condition?
questions.explanation:
This given scenario of infertility, amenorrhea and galactorrhea with elevated prolactin level 
(normal level is 0-25 ng/ml in a non-pregnant woman) is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia, and 
bromocriptine does not lead to hyperprolactinemia. It is a dopamine-agonist and hence it inhibits 
prolactin synthesis. Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in the treatment of 
hyperprolactinemia.

questions.question: Question 12: Systemic causes of hyperprolactinemia include all of the following clinical conditions except
questions.explanation:
Hypothyroidism predisposes to the development of hyperprolactinemia. 67 
Sold by @itachibot Both enhanced hypothalamic synthesis of TRH and increased pituitary-responsiveness to TRH 
have been described as the mechanism behind this phenomenon. Other systemic disorders that predispose to the development of hyperprolactinemia : • Chronic renal failure • Cirrhosis • Pseudocyesis • Epileptic seizures

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a hallmark of hyperprolactinemia in women?
questions.explanation:
The hallmarks of hyperprolactinemia in women are: • Amenorrhea – (Secondary > Primary) • Galactorrhea • Infertility In men with hyperprolactinemia, diminished libido, infertility, and visual loss (from optic nerve 
compression) are the usual presenting symptoms.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presents to your OPD with galactorrhea and amenorrhea. Apart from the 
determination of serum prolactin levels, which other investigation would you like to do?
questions.explanation:
TSH should be measured along with the prolactin level to rule out hypothyroidism which can 
cause hyperprolactinemia. Note: However, pregnancy (using qualitative HCG) should be ruled out in all women of the 
reproductive age group with amenorrhea.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 30-year-old nullipara with a desire to conceive presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. 
UPT is negative. Investigations indicate hyperprolactinemia. What is the drug of choice for 
clinical management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for clinical management of this patient would be bromocriptine. Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid and a short-acting dopamine receptor agonist. Due to its 
short-term action, it is preferred when pregnancy is desired. Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity. It 
effectively suppresses PRL secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. 68 
Sold by @itachibot Pituitary Tumours and Sheehan's Syndrome
